events.target_title: How to make Evolution ask only one time for access to gnome-keyring
How to make Evolution ask only one time for access to gnome-keyring

note.body:
Hi @aklapper .  
What I mean by "closing gnome-keyring keyrings" is:
1. Opening `seahorse`
2. Right-click on "login" keyring and clicking on "Lock" option

My `evolution` version is 3.32.2  
My distro is Manjaro Deepin x64, which is a rolling-release distro

events.target_title: How to make Evolution ask only one time for access to gnome-keyring

note.body:
The why is because of security. If my system gets malware it will not be able to get my `gnome-keyring` stored passwords because my keyring is locked and needs a password to unlock it and reveal the stored passwords.  

I only lock the `gnome-keyring` "login" keyring after `evolution` has asked for the password, so it *could*  remember (on memory, not on disk) the passwords that it needs that were asked for the first time.

Other applications, it they need a password from one of `gnome-keyring`'s keyring might ask for an unlock of "login" keyring, and after I enter the password to unlock it, I lock the opened `gnome-keyring` "login" keyring again.

There is no need to keep `gnome-keyring` keyrings unlocked if no application needs a password from it. Keeping it unlocked might be a security risk, if malware enters the system and finds all `gnome-keyring`'s passwords open for reading.

events.target_title: How to make Evolution ask only one time for access to gnome-keyring

note.body:
Maintaining `gnome-keyring` open makes easier for malware to get your "encrypted password" (not any more because the keyring is open) using a simple script like [gkeyring](https://github.com/kparal/gkeyring).  

That is why I would like `evolution` to ask access for its passwords from `gnome-keyring` one time and then, as long as `evolution` is open, not ask again (for evolution users not have to have their `gnome-keyring` open all the time because of mail checking).  

`kmail` does this (using the `kwallet`).  
`gajim` does this, using `gnome-keyring`.  
`evolution` should do this, I'm my opinion. I would give a higher level of security (not a perfect one, but a higher one)

@aklapper Does this answer your question on "how malware accesses your gnome-keyring stored passwords"?

note.body:
>  By "I make evolution fetch my emails", you mean using Send/Receive, right?

Yes, send/receive.

> What are the account types (IMAP, POP, ...) you've configured, please?

IMAP

> The password is needed only if the account is going to be connected. It doesn't ask for the password, when it is already connected. For example the IMAP accounts do not disconnect unless needed (which includes when the server disconnects, machine goes offline, or when the account is not refreshed for a long time), in contrast to POP accounts, which connect when they are refreshing and then disconnect immediately.

Maybe my email hoster or my email client (`evolution`) is disconnecting the connection after some period of time.  
I just want to keep my email client to notice me on arrival of new messages... (without keeping on asking for the `gnome-keyring` password)

events.target_title: How to make Evolution ask only one time for access to gnome-keyring

note.body:
I'm understanding that caching the password on RAM, can not bring much security.  
I just though that if an attacker (maybe not a top-notch hacker) wants to get my identity, it will target the `gnome-keyring` first, since it is a repository of passwords, and using available scripts (see above), he/she can get my passwords easily; because `gnome-keyring` has to be open for evolution to check new emails.  

This attacker may not be proficient enough to know which RAM memory address it should read to get my mail password.

That is my security mind thinking. I'm not an attacker, so I wouldn't know if storing password on RAM is better then storing in and keeping the `gnome-keyring` open.

> Do Kerberos V tickets solve your concerns?

I don't know much about Kerberos or Kerberos V tickets. I know that I have never used it.

From what I have read it is a network authentication protocol, and don't know how this applies to my use case (I'm using a email hoster, so I'm not using a email server on-premise).

I should have given a bit more context. I'm not interested in gnome-keyring because I'm implementing the DBus secret-service. I'm trying to use secret-tool to write some integration tests, to verify that the server is at least able to communicate to the standard command-line client through the real bus.

OS X ISSUES -  DEALING WITH GARBLED FONTS http://www.fontgeek.net/blog/?p=6 <http://www.fontgeek.net/blog/?p=6>

Dealing with Font Cache Problems

Another great example of this would be Helvetica. If you look at the CSS Style Sheets of MacFixit.com you will see that Helvetica is specified in certain parts of the site. This is just fine unless you have another very common Helvetica font present, once called Helvetica-Fraction. If you have Helvetica-Fraction or Helvetica-FractionBold present in wither your font manager or in one of your various OS Font folders, then this font could, and often does, get used instead of the normal Helvetica font specified. note.body:
Eureka!



Seems its a Mac problem not GiMP directly

I did

clear-font-cache.md
	• Close all applications. ( ...
	• Start Terminal (located in the Utilities folder; press Command-Shift-U to open this folder).
	• Type sudo atsutil databases -remove and press Return.
	• Type your password at the prompt (no characters will echo back to the screen).

Restarted and all is working fine!   Phew thanks for all your time looking into it - so if it crops up for other Mac folk we have a solution

John

Ok, so I did some testing by removing my .local lollypop folder and rebuilding the library, and making a bunch of smart playlists and then making a bunch of normal playlists. events.target_title: Firmware updates fail with confusing warning when low battery and on AC
rhythmbox loses daap connection everytime when dhcp lease expires
rhythmbox loses daap connection everytime when dhcp lease expires

note.body:
Hi Jonathan, I can increase the lease time on my dhcp server, but that only makes the problem occur less often, of course. Maybe there's a better solution...?

Actually I'm not sure if the network stack on the client should solve the problem (by handling the lost lease without letting the problem affect any application). Maybe rhythmbox (or avahi) is just more picky about losing the lease than other applications. On my computer it's the only application with such a problem. Video streaming clients don't care about losing the lease.

However I do have a fix (or workaround) for the problem:
```
#/etc/systemd/network/wired.network
[DHCP]
CriticalConnection=true
```
As you suggest it's not a specific fix for rhythmbox, but a general solution in the dhcp client for all application. Now my dhcp client doesn't take down the address when renewing the lease, so avahi does not forget all the services on the network anymore and the daap connection keeps running.

note.body:
I'm an i3 user myself and whilst I personally completely agree with features like this being  superfluous, when considering how I use my workstation (I don't even have nautilus installed, I use the rather minimalistic vifm as my file manager), I must admit, given the nature of the GNOME project, I'm a bit surprised you feel this is out of scope for you. 

Most casual mac users I know, such as my other half, my mother, creatives I've been exposed to throughout my career etc. All seem quite fond of the colour labelling, and I see it used quite a bit in peoples daily workflows. And while the work of devs like Bilal, will close the gap by rolling out extensions and such, I genuinely think you are missing a quite big trick by ignoring this. Its actually something casual computer users care about, and where you can "one-up" Windows, and maybe even MacOS, by making it sleeker.

events.target_title: gnome-shell 3.32.1 memory leak

note.body:
I've found steps to reproduce on Ubuntu 19.04, graphics i915:
```
cd
cd Schreibtisch  # = desktop
for F in {0..100}; do
  echo $F;
  touch Nothing;
  sleep 10;
  rm Nothing;
  sleep 10;
done
```
Key here is to do this in the desktop folder. And these sleeps are needed, because each time a file gets created or removed, CPU ramps up considerably and icons on the desktop vanish for ~ half a second.

Measurements on gnome-shell RAM usage ('RES' in *top*):
```
Initially: 235 MiB
After 10:  669 MiB
After 20:  1.0 GiB
```

This desktop icons vanishing for a moment also happens when e.g. closing a file open dialog in an application. No matter whether the dialog gets canceled or a file actually selected. And I'd bet this also increases gnome-shell memory usage like the procedure shown above.

Further info:
```
$ dpkg --list gnome-shell mutter
[...]
ii  gnome-shell    3.32.1-1ubuntu1~19.04.1 amd64        graphical shell for the GNOME desktop
ii  mutter         3.32.1-2ubuntu1~19.04.1 amd64        lightweight GTK+ window manager
```

P.S.: it's an X11 session, didn't check Wayland yet.

With pauses of 1 second I even managed to lock up Gnome entirely. Mouse still moving, CPU constantly 100%, but neither mouse clicks nor keyboard typing would get through to the intended application.

events.target_title: Unimplemented annotation: POPPLER_ANNOT_POLY_LINE

note.body:
Those annotations were generated by an Onyx Boox Note Pro e-reader, using the built-in reader app. The results are the same whether the PDF is "exported" or "merged", for what it's worth.

Evince is not the only PDF reader having trouble with those. From circumstantial evidence, I think we can assert that those work:

 * Acrobat reader
 * Emacs (which apparently uses Ghostscript)
 * `gv` (from Ghostscript)
 * PDF.js (Chromium 78 on Debian GNU/Linux 10 buster)

And that those don't:

 * Evince
 * Okular
 * XPDF
 * Zathura
 * PDF.js (Firefox ESR 68 on Debian GNU/Linux 10 buster)

Issues with the scribbling were also reported on the [Onyx forum](http://bbs.onyx-international.com/t/quality-of-exported-scribbles-is-very-poor/1426/), [twice](http://bbs.onyx-international.com/t/annotations-with-pen-with-pressure-not-displayed-in-pdf-viewer/1441).

events.target_title: Unimplemented annotation: POPPLER_ANNOT_POLY_LINE

note.body:
> I wonder what *merged* means in the context of Onyx Book Note Pro, because I would expect the annotations were flattened as strokes in the PDF, instead of annotations themselves. That makes me wonder if there could be an issue in both sides.

That's what I was hoping for, but what it actually means, I think, is that the original PDF is replaced instead of just writing a copy on the side.

I'll see if I can create a simpler test case, with and without merged mode, and with different strokes.

> That said, I would recommend to file a bug in [Poppler](https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/poppler/poppler)'s gitlab, as there is a commonality among the applications that fail to render the document. Nevertheless, it also requires a part in Evince, at least to detect them, and handle them.

I'm not sure the bug is in Poppler, because it does have that construct and detects the thing correctly. I would not know how to address the issue there...

events.target_title: Unimplemented annotation: POPPLER_ANNOT_POLY_LINE

note.body: Annotations are on PDFs. Do you have an empty page PDF handy? :)

events.target_title: Unimplemented annotation: POPPLER_ANNOT_POLY_LINE

note.body:
excellent, thanks. here's a scribble on top of that PDF:

[about_empty-Exported.pdf](/uploads/fbc3ce2394fde42211bdb7b5ae258ea0/about_empty-Exported.pdf)

... containing the following text, in the appropriate tool:

```
light pen (2)
thick pen (10)
really thick pen (20)
pencil (light, thick, really)
line: [drawing of a line using the line tool]
square: [drawing of a square]
circle: [drawing of a circle]
triangle: [drawing of a triangle]
colors: [black scribbled square] black
        [ ] red
        [ ] green
        [ ] blue
        [ ] white  <---- white
```

 * The `pen` lines are drawn with the "pen" tool (or "brush"?) with varying intensity. The "really thick" is picked by manually selecting weight "20" that is not available by just choosing the presets.
 * The `pencil` lines, and all remaining text, are drawn with the "pencil" tool (the one right of the "pen"), with varying intensity, similarly to the pen tool
 * The line, square, circle and triangles have samples of those geometric shapes that can be created with the scribbling app
 * the colors are all drawn with the pencil as well, and presumably affect other tools similarly.

This should give us a good basis covering almost all combinations. I think the only ones not covered are the colored pen and drawing tools, but i'd be suprised if they don't work right if they're black relatives do.

events.target_title: 'LeftShift+RightShift' switches layout although it's not configured to

note.body:
Same for `LeftAlt+RightAlt` if `grp:alt_shift_toggle` is set in `xkb-opttions`. It is actually a mutter bug.
This is caused by [`get_keycodes_for_keysym`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/blob/740a62044ee8f1ab1d3006c030fedaff97d78698/src/core/keybindings.c#L372) used in conjunction with `XKB_KEY_ISO_Next_Group` [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/blob/740a62044ee8f1ab1d3006c030fedaff97d78698/src/core/keybindings.c#L462). `get_keycodes_for_keysym` returns four keycodes. One for left Shift, one for left Alt, one for right Shift and one for right Alt in single `iso_next_group_combo`. So, any combination of those keys cause the layout switch.

events.target_title: gimp-2.10.12-setup-1.exe: 'Select file associations' missing

note.body: > I'm not going to bother with this. Come on, we can fix this. We have the technology. Windows 7 behaves differently because Microsoft slightly changed the file association stuff for Windows 8. And they did again with Windows 10 (they just had to throw XML at it). Looks like Windows 7 is more likely to show the old XP-style association and Windows 8 and later will show the program(s) from `OpenWithProgIds`. Is there any reason to write the default values of the `SOFTWARE\Classes\.` keys? Windows 8 and later seem to ignore it most of the time. The problem should be fixed if the lines 18 and 34 get removed from `associations.isi`. https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp/blob/96713a30c9f4fc553b3023482570df1a82960c41/build/windows/installer/associations.isi#L18 https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp/blob/96713a30c9f4fc553b3023482570df1a82960c41/build/windows/installer/associations.isi#L34 This can now even be improved. The user should have a convenient way to select the file extensions like it was possible in the old installer. Because Microsoft chose to move the file associations to the system settings, the application has to be registered in the registry where Windows can pick it up. After that, all the extensions will show up in the "defaults by app" settings for GIMP. Here's a screenshot from a test: Also works with Windows 7 and 8, which have a better interface. I'll never get why they chose "Modern UI" to be less... I do not have any experience with Inno Setup or a have build environment for GIMP, so the following is mostly a suggestion as I can't properly test it. This would obviously need translations, pulling paths and version numbers from variables, checking if the uninstall flags for the registry keys and values are appropriate, and maybe use a different name for the application registry key (are there naming conventions?). [GIMP2_register_application_and_extensions_with_windows.diff](/uploads/61a1736bd9a9386b2790e07fbb5f4348/GIMP2_register_application_and_extensions_with_windows.diff) And while I was on Windows 10, I took before and after screenshots of the files that GIMP 2.10.12 associates with after the installation. (Has no relevance to the issue, it's just for reference)

events.target_title: gimp-2.10.12-setup-1.exe: 'Select file associations' missing

note.body:
Unfortunately, once you run the installer, the previous values can only be restored from a registry backup if you have one.

If you have other systems where you want to install GIMP 2.10.12 it's of course possible to save it beforehand and then restore it afterwards.

Here's a PowerShell script that outputs a .reg file with the current default value of all the registry keys that the GIMP installer overwrites: [get_file_association_values_overwritten_by_gimp2.ps1](/uploads/e9f8f633833827c69c5593ac470c02d3/get_file_association_values_overwritten_by_gimp2.ps1).

And this is a .reg file with the default Windows 7 values: [windows_7_file_association_values_overwritten_by_gimp2.reg](/uploads/a67d9f9765f0aeca7fc8b5c445e086d7/windows_7_file_association_values_overwritten_by_gimp2.reg).

events.target_title: Allow assignment of file extensions handled by GIMP

note.body:
Note that the main issue here is that the GIMP installers (gimp-2.10.12-setup-1.exe and gimp-2.10.12-setup-2.exe) overwrite the default values of the `HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Classes\.<ext>` keys. The entries in `OpenWithProgids` are not much of a problem, as this should only show up for files that don't have any association already. The ones that have should retain their association and Windows may even offer to change it over to GIMP. (Varies by Windows version.)

There was some discussion about this in issue #3546.

I certainly agree that there has to be a way to conveniently select the associations. This can be done by properly registering GIMP in the Windows Registry. (Also discussed in the other issue.)

Reverting to the last known association is problematic on newer versions of Windows. I guess it's frowned upon to touch these settings without user knowledge. If the ProgID vanishes, Windows will ask the user which program to use anyway.

events.target_title: gimp-2.10.12-setup-1.exe: 'Select file associations' missing

note.body:
Uninstalling GIMP should remove the responsible registry keys, yes. The offending ones may be the default values of these depending if you installed it for all or only your user.

```
HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Classes\.pdf
HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Classes\.pdf
```

Check if they have `GIMP2.pdf` as the default value and delete it. To update the association and icon cache you can use this PowerShell script, then you don't have to restart Explorer or Windows.

[SHChangeNotify_ASSOCCHANGED_IDLIST_FLUSH.ps1](/uploads/dce2102f38410a474f961517402d711a/SHChangeNotify_ASSOCCHANGED_IDLIST_FLUSH.ps1)

It is possible that Family Tree Maker has its own cache in which the script may not work.

And, as schumaml mentioned, the new installer should indeed behave better, but I have not tested it yet.

events.target_title: gimp-2.10.12-setup-1.exe: 'Select file associations' missing

note.body:
Changing the associations usually triggers what the script does, so I don't think that's going to help much at this point. You can run it by opening `cmd.exe` and then type `powershell -ExecutionPolicy bypass -File SHChangeNotify_ASSOCCHANGED_IDLIST_FLUSH.ps1` with the correct path to the ps1 file.

Windows does like to put registry entries in a few places once one of the associations get activated, but that really should not have an effect on that icon.

Uninstalling GIMP removes the file with the icon from your system so my guess is that it's in a cache somewhere. I thought the Explorer icon cache gets rebuilt after a restart or association change (there are some resources on the internet that will explain how to delete the cache).

Is there any other program still showing the icon? A more freely available software would make it easier to test if I get the same issue here.

events.target_title: gimp-2.10.12-setup-1.exe: 'Select file associations' missing

note.body:
The new installer behaves better, but it still adds some registry entries that make Windows show the icon on files without an association. To fix that you can run one of these reg files depending if you installed GIMP for all users or just your user.

All users: [GIMP_2.10.12_remove_OpenWithProgids_all_users.reg](/uploads/d63d7700d4242af78ce3086946853b1e/GIMP_2.10.12_remove_OpenWithProgids_all_users.reg) (Requires administrator privileges)

Current user: [GIMP_2.10.12_remove_OpenWithProgids_current_user.reg](/uploads/23dbc6cb02295092c32df52334d6fbf9/GIMP_2.10.12_remove_OpenWithProgids_current_user.reg)

These remove the GIMP values in the OpenWithProgids registry keys. Windows may use these entries if a file doesn't have any association yet. You can use the PowerShell script to refresh the icon cache. A restart or changing a file association in the control panel may also have the same effect.

Please note that Explorer also creates per-user registry entries if some file association gets activated by the user. If not all icons are gone we have to look where these values are. I think they are in `HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\FileExts`, but be careful with deleting random stuff.

I'm really not sure how GIMP could have caused the error message issue with that application.

I used sysprof during the ~5 second gnome shell freeze after clicking "cancel" in the gedit "file open" dialog, and both handlers_find and handler_lookup showed up at the top for "[pool-gnome-shel]" (but I'm not sure if the freeze could be at a different place, maybe in the kernel, and sysprof just thinks that it's in those functions because that's where execution gets stuck during the freeze?).

Is there an easy way to find out if my system suffers from excessive gsignal handler lists without recompiling glib? Maybe using (custom) application code? The search box in epiphany-browser seems to work fine.

It might be worth noting that this only happens in my own user profile, so it's probably caused by something in my /home dir.

Let me know if there is anything I can do to help debug this.

Edit to add: I attached gdb to gnome-shell, and g_handler_list_bsa_ht has size=131072. I'm not sure if that's expected, it seems like a lot?
Edit 2: This is using Ubuntu 19.04 and the Ubuntu extensions (dock, desktop icons and App indicators). Is there a way to find out what kind of handlers cause this?

events.target_title: Lag When Opening Activities Overview

note.body:
The !763 fix should be in 3.34.2.

I will note that on my 3.34.1 / Ubuntu 19.10 system, gjs does tons of g_irepository_find_by_gtype() lookups for two interface types (MetaCullable and MetaScreenCastWindow) that have no public type information in the gi-repository. Maybe those are triggered by accessing window properties in javascript (window actor implements both Cullable and ScreenCastWindow interfaces) like `a.realWindow.x` etc. for the sort criterion did before !763 was applied.

g_irepository_find_by_gtype() has a cache for types that actually exist in the repository, but since Cullable and ScreenCastWindow are not in the gi-repository, all those lookups are pretty slow since NULL results are not cached. This leads to scanning any loaded namespace twice, once using a local-only prefix search, and again using a "global" search, where all registered type names are compared to the wanted type, using strcmp, so that's slow.

events.target_title: Window overview on current workspace (Super hotkey) takes half a second after longer uptime (Flamegraphs attached)

note.body:
I see g_irepository_find_by_gtype, which is called by js::GetProperty, is kind of important in that flame graph for the gnome-shell portion (like 30% of it). gnome-shell javascript code used to access window properties (x/y coords) for a sort comparator when sorting windows for the window overview. Since the sort algorithm needs to call the comparator a lot if more than very few windows are open, there was lots of JS property access. And JS property access was slow because it called g_irepository_find_by_gtype on gtypes which are not public, leading to multiple full scans of all types in the gi repository every time a window property (like the x or y coord) was accessed in JS.

The "multiple full scans of the repository on window property access" was fixed in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gobject-introspection/commit/441926c7d5da515c865a3bc4a3d1d996a6b64b67 , which will be in 3.36.

Also, there was a stop-gap measure applied for 3.34.2, where the x/y window coords are cached in pure JS variables before starting the window sorting, which helps a lot with many open windows because the full girepository scan is only executed a few times while opening the overview. https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/commit/072a9a4842673355535098edd4748d689b913bf1

I suspect the flame graph looks better already in current 3.34, and then even better in 3.36. Not sure if it's already good enough to close this bug. But the flame graph is most likely outdated and not representative of current git master behavior.

events.target_title: Loop until overflow - RDP identification changed
Loop until overflow - RDP identification changed

note.body:
In frdp-session.c frdp_session_connect_thread has error checking and the ERRCONNECT_CONNECT_CANCELLED (0x2000B) returned by freerdp is ignored. 

I added error to authentication_errors variable and it worked, but i think this should be solved differently.

Below you can find fast fix for this issue.

```
UINT32 error_code = freerdp_get_last_error (self->priv->freerdp_session->context);
      g_debug ("Failed to connect RPD host with error '%s'", freerdp_get_last_error_string( error_code ) );
      authentication_errors +=
          error_code == 0x20009 ||
          error_code == 0x2000c ||
          error_code == 0x20005 ||
          error_code == 0x2000B;
```

note.body:
@aklapper "Blip" just means graphic popping into view without a transition. In this bug report's case, the blip happens *right* after entering in the lock screen password. Your desktop appears into view without a transition effect.

I'm running Fedora 30 on 2 devices, A PC with an nVidia card + Skylake i7, and a laptop with Intel integrated graphics. Stock GNOME 3.32.2 with no extensions or themes.

note.body:
Hello, I am also affected, me too on arch linux. I will paste here a comment by another user on extensions.gnome.org which may be related:

> On Arch Linux, since the update to gnome-shell 1:3.32.2+1+g24cb1c1aa-1 on the 5th of June, enabling the "Show the Trash icon in the desktop" icon makes all icons disappear. Also, adding or removing desktop files rearranges them all starting in the top left corner, so whatever custom arrangement you might have had gets broken. This even happens when you don't interact with the desktop directly (like saving a file to desktop from another app or deleting a file from the Desktop folder in Nautilus).
>
> — burafino

The same update that is apparently causing this problem, was also the beginning of the disappearance issue. I've been without icons for the last month, until I read this and switched off the trash. Now I'm seeing icons lose their position as reported by other people above. Not sure whether this is a related problem or should be reported in its own issue instead.

```
[...irrelevant things...]
GNOME Shell started at Fri Jun 28 2019 11:10:59 GMT+0200 (CEST)
Error loading desktop files Operation not supported
```

events.target_title: Multi-touch touchpad scrolling not working

note.body:
On Ubuntu 18.04, in a Gnome Shell Wayland session, zoom works using a 2-finger 'pinch' gesture. Using a 2-finger panning gesture to 'scroll' doesn't work however. This was tested on eog version 3.28.1.

When using a mouse scrollwheel a zoom is performed.

I think that for touchpad gestures the behavior should match that of the document viewer ('evince'), i.e. 2-finger pinch for zoom and 2-finger pan to scroll in any direction. Not sure what is the sensible behavior for a mouse scrollwheel however.

events.target_title: WIP: clutter/stage: Process input events out of phase with redraws [performance]

note.body:
I second that. Furthermore, for real-time audio it's not just the jitter to worry about but the latency as well. "Pro audio" apps work very hard to achieve the lowest possible latency.

It is important to remember that the relevant input devices include more than the usual keyboard and a mouse - there are audio-specific controllers, midi keyboards etc. Ideally input events destined for real-time audio applications should be delivered ASAP.

Having said that, I think that it shouldn't block this pull request, since in the existing code input events are already batched. However this is something to think about for a future change.

events.target_title: WIP: clutter/stage: Process input events out of phase with redraws [performance]

note.body:
I'm not sure I fully understand !168, however from the description it seems that input events are still sometimes batched. Input events should never be batched for pro-audio apps.

For pro-audio apps the GUI is of secondary importance. The highest priority is satisfying the audio frames on time. It is not uncommon to have 1,000 audio frames per second - for example a sample rate of 48,000 and a frame size of 48 samples. So these apps have at least 2 'clocks', the display clock which is usually at about 60Hz and the audio clock which could be configured to various values beforehand. Tying the input events to the display clock makes no sense for these apps.

I think that the best approach would be to let the application choose if it wants the compositor to batch input events or not. However I'm not acquainted with the Wayland protocols, and implementing that is probably well outside the scope of this MR - which is why I think it should not block merging it.

events.target_title: Multi-touch touchpad scrolling not working

note.body:
I'm using a touchpad (Apple external 'trackpad' v1).

> A two-finger rotational movement should rotate the image by the way. I can't verify as I am missing the necessary hardware. 

On my machine this only results in 90 degrees rotation, is this the intended behavior? Or does it have free rotation when using a touchscreen... A free rotation would be cool, anyway, even when using a touchpad.

> The two-finger panning gesture is wired to go to the next/previous picture, depending on direction. Of course this only works if there is another picture to go to. Scrolling should work by simply dragging the image around once zoomed in.

That gives me an idea for an enhancement. When the picture is smaller than or fits in the window, keep the existing behavior of going to the next/prev picture. However when the picture is zoomed in so that it doesn't fit in the window, switch to a (omni-direction) panning behavior. Does that make sense? For what it's worth, this is the behavior on my Android phone.

events.target_title: Input events are not synchronized to the screen refresh

note.body:
Ah ok, this is another thing I probably wasn't clear about. I wasn't talking about the kinetic animation caused by a fling gesture - it doesn't work when kinetic scroll is disabled. I'm talking about the stick-to-finger gesture - that is, keeping the fingers on the trackpad, as per your second comment. I'll update the description to make that more clear.

Anyway the difference is most obvious when keeping the fingers on the trackpad and trying to scroll in a relatively slow speed. When scrolling faster it's indeed harder to tell.

events.target_title: Input events are not synchronized to the screen refresh

note.body:
> If there was a way to make scrolling more smooth *without sacrificing a millisecond of latency*, that would be obviously good, but I strongly oppose any sort of animation style approach that makes it not feel truly instant. 

By all means I don't think that smooth scroll should be forced, since it will always be a trade-off with latency. Furthermore with smooth scrolling the GTK app will optimally not get more than a single scroll event per frame, whereas some apps will want better input event granularity for whatever reason.

I was thinking about a per-widget configuration option available to the programmer of the GTK application, to choose whether to enable smooth scroll for that widget or not. Similar to the `kinetic-scrolling` property that exists today for enabling/kinetic scrolling on `GtkScrolledWindow`.

Some applications will choose to always enable, some never and some will make it configurable. For example Firefox *already* has a user-facing 'official' option (in about:preferences, General -> Browsing - 'Use smooth scrolling') for whether to enable smooth scrolling or not.

events.target_title: Menu item for GAction always disabled (gtk_widget_insert_action_group)

note.body:
Okay, but how can I achieve what I'm trying to do here? I want to have different actions for different widgets, but they may use the same accelerator. I only want the accelerator to trigger when the widget is focused.

For example, one of my widgets has an action that is bound to Ctrl+C. Now the problem is, if I add this action globally, then *all* Ctrl+C presses will be caught and I'm no longer able to copy text using Ctrl+C in other widgets.

I tried using GtkBindingSet for this before, but it has two problems:
1. There is no easy way for the user to change the accelerator.
2. Signals triggered by a GtkBindingSet only support a very limited set of parameter types like int and float, whereas GAction supports GVariant and is thus much more flexible.

It seemed to me like using `gtk_widget_insert_action_group` would be the way to go. And it actually works as intended for accelerators. The only problem is that it doesn't work in the menu.
